::: {#prp-categorical-indicators}

## One-Hot Indicator Equivalence for Categorical Conditionals

Let $Y$ be a categorical random variable $Y \sim \text{cat}_k(\pmb{\pi})$, taking values in $\{1,\dots,C\}$ with class probabilities $\pi_c>0$, $\sum_{c=1}^C\pi_c=1, \forall \pi_c \in \pmb{\pi}$. Let a random variable $X=(X_1,\dots,X_J)$ and assume conditional independence of components given $Y$ so that for each $c$,
$$
p(X\mid Y=c)=\prod_{j=1}^J p(X_j\mid Y=c).
$$

Define the one-hot indicator vector
$$
\mathbf{Y}=(Y_1,\dots,Y_C),\qquad Y_c=\mathbb{1}\{Y=c\},\qquad \sum_{c=1}^C Y_c=1.
$$
Then the two expressions
$$
	\text{(I)}\qquad p(X,Y)=p(Y)\prod_{j=1}^J p(X_j\mid Y),
\qquad
	\text{(II)}\qquad p(X,\mathbf{Y})=\prod_{c=1}^C\Bigl[\pi_c\prod_{j=1}^J p(X_j\mid \mathbf{Y}=c)\Bigr]^{Y_c}
$$
are equivalent (they define the same joint probability function).

:::

::: {.proof}
Let the realized class be $c^\ast$, so $Y=c^\ast$ and $Y_{c^\ast}=1$ while $Y_c=0$ for $c\neq c^\ast$. Evaluate (II) at that realization:
$$
\prod_{c=1}^C\Bigl[\pi_c\prod_{j=1}^J p(X_j\mid Y=c)\Bigr]^{Y_c}
= \Bigl[\pi_{c^\ast}\prod_{j=1}^J p(X_j\mid Y=c^\ast)\Bigr]^{1}
\prod_{c\neq c^\ast}\bigl[\cdots\bigr]^{0}.
$$
Factors raised to the zero power equal $1$, so the product reduces to
$$
\pi_{c^\ast}\prod_{j=1}^J p(X_j\mid Y=c^\ast),
$$
which equals (I) evaluated at $Y=c^\ast$. Since the above holds for every possible realized class $c^\ast$, (I) and (II) coincide as functions of $(X,Y)$.
:::
